prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user wants to know if the author of this scenario is in the wrong. The situation is that the author, who's in a relationship, has been paying all the bills because their girlfriend only works part-time. Then there was an incident where he asked her to pay for takeout because he left his wallet, and she reacted negatively. Now he's considering making her start paying some bills, even though it's just one incident.

First, I need to analyze the dynamics here. The author is taking a stance that because of this one incident, he wants her to start contributing more. But is that fair? Well, the girlfriend's part-time job might mean she has limited income. The author has been covering everything before, which might have been an agreement or just his choice. The incident where she refused to pay for takeout could be due to feeling taken for granted or maybe she was stressed. 

The key points to consider: Is it reasonable to change financial responsibilities over a single incident? The author is using this as a catalyst to make her contribute more, but is that justified? Financial responsibilities in a relationship should ideally be discussed and agreed upon. If the author never discussed this before and is now making a change based on one event, that might be unfair. Also, the way he's framing it as "just out of principal" suggests it's more about feeling she should contribute rather than her actual ability. 

On the other hand, maybe the author has been shouldering all the costs for a long time, and this incident highlighted an imbalance. However, the approach of using a minor incident to demand a change in financial responsibilities might come across as punitive. The girlfriend's reaction could be valid if she felt the request was sudden or if she wasn't prepared to contribute. 

So, the author might be in the wrong because he's making a significant change in their financial arrangement based on a minor incident without considering their communication history. It's possible that open discussion about shared responsibilities would have been more appropriate than using this incident as a reason to shift the financial burden. The author's frustration is understandable, but the method of addressing it might be unfair.
